newsitem.title: USA: CSCE cocoa ends weaker in dull, pre-holiday trade.
newsitem.headline: CSCE cocoa ends weaker in dull, pre-holiday trade.

text.p: CSCE cocoa futures ended slightly lower Friday, but trading was sluggish ahead of the holiday weekend, dealers said.
CSCE will be closed Monday in observance of U.S. Memorial Day. London's LIFFE cocoa market will also be closed Monday.
CSCE July futures ended down $2 at $1,461 a tonne, traded $1,471 to $1,452. Second-month September slipped the same to $1,491, while the back months sagged $2 to $6.

Cocoa prices took a downturn at the outset, as expected, on the heels of a weak showing in the London cocoa market overnight. Traders said light local and trade selling pushed the July contract to a low of $1,452 -- just shy of key support at $1,445-$1,440.
But some shortcovering by locals ahead of the long weekend helped to lift prices off session lows, they added.
Technically, traders pegged July near-term resistance at $1,475, but said July would need to get past $1,490 and a chart gap between $1,498 and $1,501 to inspire substantial buying.
On the fundamental side, German cocoa trader Albrecht & Dill GmbH said on Friday the Ivory Coast could have sold 550,000 tonnes from its upcoming 1997/98 cocoa main crop (October/September).

A&D's weekly report cited information received from shippers and added this would be a higher figure than so far expected. Some sources even estimated sales in excess of 600,000 tonnes, the report said.
Volume reached an estimated 4,852 lots. ((--Patricia Avidan, New York Commodity Desk +1 212 859 1640))
